title: CPR for Adults
description: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is a lifesaving technique that's useful in many emergencies, such as a heart attack or near drowning, in which someone's breathing or heartbeat has stopped.
steps: Check the scene for safety and tap the person to see if they respond.
Call 911 or ask someone else to do so.
Place the person on their back on a firm, flat surface.
Kneel beside the person's neck and shoulders.
Place the heel of one hand over the center of the person's chest, between the nipples.
Place your other hand on top of the first hand. Keep your elbows straight and position your shoulders directly above your hands.
Use your upper body weight to push straight down on the chest at least 2 inches but not more than 2.4 inches. Push hard at a rate of 100 to 120 compressions a minute.
If you haven't been trained in CPR, continue chest compressions until help arrives.
If you have been trained in CPR, go on to opening the airway and rescue breathing.
dosList: Allow complete chest recoil after each compression
Use an AED as soon as it's available
dontsList: Don't push too slowly or too softly
Don't lean on the chest between compressions
Don't interrupt CPR unless absolutely necessary

title: Choking Relief for Adults
description: Choking occurs when a foreign object becomes lodged in the throat or windpipe, blocking the flow of air. The Heimlich maneuver is an emergency technique to help clear the airway.
steps: Stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist.
Tilt the person slightly forward.
Make a fist with one hand and place it slightly above the person's navel.
Grasp your fist with the other hand and press hard into the abdomen with a quick, upward thrust.
Repeat thrusts until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious.
If the person becomes unconscious, lower them to the ground and begin CPR.
dosList: Act quickly if you see someone choking
Call 911 if the object doesn't dislodge quickly
dontsList: Don't slap the person's back while they're upright
Don't perform abdominal thrusts on pregnant women or obese individuals (use chest thrusts instead)

title: Burns Treatment
description: Burns are tissue damage caused by heat, chemicals, electricity, sunlight, or radiation. First-degree burns affect only the outer layer of skin, second-degree burns affect both the outer and underlying layer of skin, and third-degree burns affect deeper tissues.
steps: Ensure the person is no longer in contact with the burning source.
Remove jewelry, belts and tight clothing.
For minor burns (first-degree), cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for 10 to 15 minutes.
Don't apply ice directly to the burn.
Apply lotion or moisturizer to prevent drying and provide relief.
For second-degree burns, follow the same cooling process but don't break blisters.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-stick bandage.
For third-degree burns, call 911 immediately, cover the area with a clean cloth, and elevate the burned area above heart level if possible.
dosList: Cool the burn with cool running water
Cover with a clean, dry cloth
Take over-the-counter pain relievers if needed
dontsList: Don't use ice, as it may cause further damage
Don't apply butter, oil, or ointments to severe burns
Don't remove stuck clothing from burned areas

title: Bleeding Control
description: Severe bleeding can be life-threatening and requires immediate action to control blood loss until medical help arrives.
steps: Wash your hands if possible and put on gloves if available.
Remove any obvious debris or dirt from the wound.
Apply direct pressure to the wound using a clean cloth, gauze pad, or bandage.
Maintain pressure for 15 minutes.
If blood soaks through, add more gauze or cloth without removing the original material.
If the bleeding is from an arm or leg, elevate the limb above the heart while maintaining pressure.
If bleeding continues and you suspect an artery is involved, apply pressure to the appropriate pressure point (brachial for arm, femoral for leg).
As a last resort for life-threatening limb bleeding, apply a tourniquet if you have proper training.
Secure the wound with a bandage once bleeding stops.
Seek medical attention.
dosList: Apply direct pressure to the wound
Keep the injured person still and calm
dontsList: Don't remove large or deeply embedded objects
Don't remove the first cloth if it becomes soaked with blood
Don't apply a tourniquet unless you have proper training

title: Fracture Care
description: A fracture is a broken bone. It requires proper immobilization and medical attention to ensure proper healing.
steps: Stop any bleeding by applying pressure to the wound with a sterile bandage, a clean cloth, or a clean piece of clothing.
Immobilize the injured area. Don't try to realign the bone.
Apply ice packs wrapped in a cloth to limit swelling and help relieve pain.
Treat for shock if necessary by laying the person flat, elevating the feet about 12 inches, and covering them with a coat or blanket.
Call 911 or seek immediate medical help if the person is unresponsive, isn't breathing or moving, has heavy bleeding, or if you suspect a fracture in the neck, head, or back.
dontsList: Don't move the person unless absolutely necessary
Don't attempt to straighten a broken bone
Don't move joints or bones near the injury
